Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Decision-Theoretic and Scalable Algorithms for Computing Finite State Equilibrium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is exploring algorithms for computing multiagent strategies that are in exact and approximate equilibrium. The context involves economic games that are played repeatedly by agents each of whom privately observes noisy signals about other players' actions. A complete characterization of equilibria for such games, missing until recently, introduces the concept of a finite state equilibrium in which each player's strategy is represented as a finite state automaton. Players' strategies are verified to be in equilibrium by solving a partially observable Markov decision process. The research is building on this surprising and deep application of decision theory toward equilibrium analysis in a pragmatic class of games, which provides a bold and innovative bridge between decision and game theories. It is designing novel algorithms that utilize approximate and error-bounded solutions of partially observable Markov decision processes for computing approximate finite state equilibrium in games with increasing dimensions.

This research is contributing insights for broader classes of games such as stochastic games with noisy signals. The interdisciplinary outcomes of this research are being integrated into courses and conference tutorials on multiagent decision making for dissemination. New international research collaborations with eminent multiagent researchers in Japan are being established.

This research is bringing together the disciplines of decision and game theories with mutual benefit. Key outcomes include scalable algorithms for solving highly complex games thereby contributing to the understanding of sophisticated interactions under uncertainty. Applications include analyzing auctions without release of public information, covert price wars between firms, and managing resource congestion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under intellectual merit, this EAGER project studied new characterizations of equilibrium in a broad class of repeated games in which strategies are represented as finite state automata. It studied the class of repeated games with possibly imperfect private monitoring, which is one of the most realistic (and complex) class of repeated games under study currently. A crucial feature of this setting is that players do not share common information. The project introduced a refinement of the previously established equilibrium concept for these games that is robust to deviations from equilibrium paths; developed a computational method to verify the correctness of these robust equilibria; and analyzed its asymptotic complexity. It established that the decision problem of verifying the equilibrium for given k players is in NP if P is not equal to NP.

The project also explored the first algorithm for finding a finite state equilibrium. This algorithm brings to bear techniques from decision theory to this problem, and thus provides a way to bridge the gap between decision and game theories both of which seek to model how agents may act rationally.

Two applications of this class of repeated games were formulated for conducting future experiments. (a) A first-price and sealed-bid auction where the auctioneer withholds all information and the participants solely know the outcome of winning or losing the auction (which cannot be withheld). The auctioneer has an incentive to withhold all information to fight collusion. Repeated instances of such auctions may be modeled within the framework of repeated games with imperfect and private monitoring. (b) Smart energy grids are power grids that are significantly more decentralized, computerized and flexible compared to conventional grids. The problem of allocating power-grid capacity in a smart grid over a period of time to multiple aggregators may be modeled as a sealed-bid auction where the auctioneer privately informs each aggregator whether it won or lost the auction only.

Under broader impact, this EAGER project established an active collaboration with Prof. Makoto Yokoo, an eminent multiagent systems professor at Kyushu University, Japan and Prof. Michihiro Kandori, an eminent professor of economics at Tokyo University, Japan. It also trained a graduate student in the field of algorithmic game theory. He graduated with a Masters degree and joined the STEM workforce of the nation.
